subject: Art
title: Texture Techniques
description: Sgraffito, stippling, sponging, and other surface effects.

hook.text: A painting's surface should be as interesting up close as it is from afar. Texture techniques add physical variety: scratches, dots, sponge marks, and scraping â€” surfaces that invite touch and reward close inspection.

buildup.text: Techniques: sgraffito (scratch through wet paint to reveal color beneath), stippling (dab with brush tip for dots), sponging (dab with sponge for organic texture), dry brush (drag almost-dry brush for rough strokes), and stamping (press objects into wet paint).

discovery.text: Texture variation creates visual interest: smooth passages make textured passages more exciting, and vice versa. A painting that's ALL texture is as monotonous as one that's ALL smooth. Contrast is key.

twist.text: Found-object stamping: press bubble wrap, leaves, corrugated cardboard, or string into wet paint. The real-world texture transfers to the canvas, creating patterns that would be impossible to paint by hand â€” and uniquely organic.

climax.text: On a practice surface, try 6 different texture techniques side by side: sgraffito, stippling, sponging, dry brush, stamping with bubble wrap, and palette knife scraping. You'll build a texture vocabulary for future paintings.

punchline.text: Texture is the painting's tactile dimension â€” what you'd feel if you could touch it. Make the surface as expressive as the image.

quiz.question: What is sgraffito?
options: Scratching through wet paint to reveal the color or layer beneath
